text.div:
English

Generated Narrative: StructureDefinition be-model-allergyintolerance

NameFlagsCard.TypeDescription & Constraints
be-model-allergyintolerance 0..*ElementAllergy Intolerance Logical Model

Elements defined in Ancestors:@id, extension
patient 1..1Reference()The person that has the allergy
code 1..1CodeableConceptThe substance that the person is allergic to
category 0..*codeThe category of the risk (food, medication, environment, biological,...). This information will not be encoded by the Recorder but can automatically be added using the SNOMED-CT code from causative agent
type 0..1codeThe Type - whether it is an allergy or intolerance
status 0..1BackboneElementThe status of the allergy
clinicalStatus 1..1CodeableConceptThe status of the allergy - if it is active or resolved
verificationStatus 1..1CodeableConceptThe verification status of the allergy - if it is confirmed or suspected or refuted
recordedDate 1..1dateTimewhen the allergy/intolerance was recorded
recorder 1..1Reference()Who recorded the allergy
asserter 0..1Reference()Who asserted the allergy
note 0..1stringAdditional text note about the allergy or intolerance
reactions 0..*BackboneElementknown past reactions to the allergen
manifestation 1..1CodeableConceptHow the reaction manifested itself
onset 0..1dateTimeManifestation date
note 0..1stringAdditional text note about the allergic reaction

Documentation for this format

Documentation for this format

element.short: Allergy Intolerance Logical Model
element.definition: Allergy / Intolerance information model

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Unique id for inter-element referencing
element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.short: Additional content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: The person that has the allergy
element.definition: The person that has the allergy

element.short: The substance that the person is allergic to
element.definition: The substance - from a lst of substances - that the person is allergic to. It is possible to use free text but for the products indicated, a code must be used

element.short: The category of the risk (food, medication, environment, biological,...). This information will not be encoded by the Recorder but can automatically be added using the SNOMED-CT code from causative agent
element.definition: The category of the risk (food, medication, environment, biological,...). This information will not be encoded by the Recorder but can automatically be added using the SNOMED-CT code from causative agent

element.short: The Type - whether it is an allergy or intolerance
element.definition: the type of risk (allergy, intolerance...). When it is not possible to distinguish between a real allergy, a non-allergic hypersensitivity or an intolerance you can use the 'Intolerance' type, but code the VerificationStatus as 'Unconfirmed'

element.short: The status of the allergy
element.definition: The status of the allergy

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

element.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored even if unrecognized
element.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element and that modifies the understanding of the element in which it is contained and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/extensibility.html#modifierExtension).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the element that contains them

element.short: The status of the allergy - if it is active or resolved
element.definition: The status of the allergy - if it is active or resolved

element.short: The verification status of the allergy - if it is confirmed or suspected or refuted
element.definition: The verification status of the allergy - if it is confirmed or suspected or refuted

element.short: when the allergy/intolerance was recorded
element.definition: when the allergy/intolerance was recorded

element.short: Who recorded the allergy
element.definition: Who recorded the allergy

element.short: Who asserted the allergy
element.definition: Is the person at the source of the information (eg the patient, the general practitioner, a family member, the healthcare professional who registers the information himself, ...). He is represented as much as possible by a unique identification number, namely the national register number (INSZ) or the BIS number. However, when it comes to a parent or family member, only the role (e.g. father, mother, neighbor, caregiver, friend, etc.) is coded to meet the requirements of the GDPR.

element.short: Additional text note about the allergy or intolerance
element.definition: Additional text note about the allergy or intolerance

element.short: known past reactions to the allergen
element.definition: known past reactions to the allergen

element.short: How the reaction manifested itself
element.definition: How the reaction manifested itself, e.g. rash, breathing difficulty...

element.short: Manifestation date
element.definition: For each manifestation it is possible to specify an actual date or approximate date (age, period, interval, ...) of each suspected manifestation of the risk
